title: What will be the closing value of the Turkish lira against the US dollar on 26 May 2022?
preds: Don't know why the consensus has gone to 95%. USDTRY is at 16.3, it could easily bounce to the other side tomorrow.
If only I had stuck with my initial forecast on this...
It is also among the news that the central bank called large companies and demanded that they sell dollars.

Rate jumped over 16 today.  However we are still very close and the normal variation could take us either side of the bin 5 threshold randomly. As the trend has generally been upwards I am nudging a slight higher bin 5 probability, but not by too much in case…..

Didn't think it'd close the 16.00 mark this fast but here we are two days before closing! Another forecast just on or over the threshold right around closing. Some of these questions are designed with almost surgical precision.
Dollars can be sold at any time, in addition, Erdogan is preparing to issue inflation-protected bonds  https://www.tcmb.gov.tr/wps/wcm/connect/tr/tcmb+tr/main+page+site+area/bugun
Apparently, the market is not done with Turkey yet.
Resistance at 16.00 seems to be holding at the moment. I suspect that will probably hold for the remainder of this question now.
Re affirming forecast, it’s a total toss up at this point
Looks like 16 might be a threshold.  Backing off as only a few days away and with the rate being 15.9+ it could go either way.
The rate has move up. May stablise at 15.85
15.96 right now.  Will probably go over 16 today or tomorrow.  There is likelihood of small recoveries that  could nudge below 16 in the next week.  Can’t go to 100% because of that, but close.

"Lira Plunges Ninth Day as Turkish Banks Cut Down Dollar Sales
 Lira is world’s third-worst performing currency this year
 Global risk aversion worsens Turkey’s idiosyncratic risks State-owned banks sold more than $1 billion to support the currency over the past two days, but the pace of interventions slowed on Tuesday, according to traders who asked not to be identified because they’re not authorized to speak publicly. Lira weakened as much as 2.1% to 15.8838, the weakest level since December. The currency has retreated 16% this year, the worst performer in the world except Sri Lanka’s rupee and Ghana’s cedi." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-05-17/lira-plunges-ninth-day-as-turkish-banks-cut-down-dollar-sales
Keeps going. High energy prices and slowdown elsewhere won’t help.
15.83 by the time this was written

As @SE_Meyer pointed out, TRY has been weakening rapidly and projections suggest this will go on beyond the last bracket by the date the question resolves. Apparently Erdogan might implement 'unconventional' solutions that could be ineffective: https://www.ft.com/content/32999c60-d0ab-44cc-a0d0-2b2496b06ed3.

Only 0.34 TRY or 2.2% left to go, today's change being 1.1% so far as of now. Unless the Turkish government comes up with a smart plan with immediate effect, it's easy to see TRY to weaken to 17 or higher before this question ends.

This looks like it is going to end very close to 16.  But which side we ask? There are 10 days to go and it is slowly creeping up.  If it continues at this rate it will be just about on 16.  It probably all depends on whether the Turkish government does something financial and what that something is.  Sill little sign that it will turn the tide, but it’s very unpredictable.  I’m going to up the likelihood of over 16 as everything is going in one direction at the moment.  Let’s call it 50/50.
I think I haven't paid enough attention to this forecast.

Looks like the slide is now restarting. I think it will go over 16 in the coming months, but not confident it will happen in the next 14 days.  The bank deposit mechanism put in place to discourage selling the Lira will soon also start to have a structurally inflationary effect I believe as more Lira will have to be created to make up for the FX losses on those accounts. I think there is a chance this all starts to snowball quite rapidly so I've increased the likelihood for the last bin.
Correcting last forecast due to typo - apparently the lira might devalue to 16.00 or more in the following week.

Lira weakened a step again and is at 15.3 at the moment.  This isn’t far from the 16 threshold. None of the financial situations have changed in Turkey and it seems unlikely that any positions will change.  If the rate keeps creeping up at this rate is will be close or over 16 by the 25th.

Fresh 2022 low at 15.18 today, probably due to worsening domestic inflation situation (measured  at ~70%), high dependency on wheat import from the Black Sea region and, as the chaos in Ukraine appears to have settled somewhat for the time being, international investors refocusing on other crisis hot spots of the world. Erdogan not having tackeled the root causes of his economic crisis but, instead, banking on permanent staff rotation and voodoo monetary policy, is almost a guarantee for a next wave of devaluation. Time is short - only two and a half weeks left -, but as of now, only ~5.5% change left, too.
I haven't kept up with this forecast enough.
Haven't run a simulation since I'm traveling... This is just a guess

The rate has stabilised out at around 14.7 over the last few weeks.  Wild swings are caused by unexpected announcements.  There is now less opportunity for these as there is only a month to go, and the market is already prepared for Erdogans counterintuitive logic. In the currently climate any such announcement I feel is more likely to increase the rate than decrease it, but staying in the bounds of 14 to 16 seems most likely at the moment.

Currency fluctuations drive % vote variance, but USD transactions can stabilize the short term projection - 
main causes of recent increases state monetary policy + war; short term projection of each of them, hence further decline But the result can be highly influenced by the revelations made on May 26.

The Turkish lira is depreciating slowly but surely. After a 5-day significant drop in Dec 2021, Erdogan announced a new plan (https://www.bbc.com/news/business-59740185) that brought up the value for some days, and then it dropped once again and continued to take almost pre-measures levels and then it kept going down - this whole perturbation lasted around 2 weeks in total. So I think it is likely that the current trend will remain in the following six weeks.
Over 14 since March 3. 60%+ inflation continues to take the economic situation from bad to worse.

It hasn’t been below 14 for a month now. More risk for upside than downside in this self-made crisis.  “There is still enormous underlying depreciation potential for the lira. The only question is when and why (what is going to be the catalyst?) this potential will be realised.”
https://www.fxstreet.com/news/usd-try-lira-to-face-enormous-underlying-depreciation-potential-commerzbank-202203280645 “The Institute of International Finance (IIF) downgraded the fair value of the Turkish lira by 42 percent to 16.5 per dollar.”
https://news.am/eng/news/693696.html
Erdogan continues the low interest rate while the war in Ukraine is going to make Turkeys gas and wheat imports from Russia more expensive.
Boosting 16 or higher because the grip on the current rate seems to be slipping
https://tradingeconomics.com/turkey/currency There’s a slow creep upwards and with flight to the dollar in times of uncertainty the pressure is in the worsening direction really.

At the time of this forecast the Turkish Lira is sitting at ~$14.21. The Turkish Lira has been in free fall lately as inflation is starting to run away hitting a 20-year high of 54.44% on a year-on-year basis in February. Turkey has been hit by the global wave of inflation just as many other countries around the world have been. This wave of inflation has been further exacerbated by Erdogan's insistence  that the Turkish central bank continue to cut interest rates running counter to conventional economic thought on how to control inflation. Going to far as to replace members of monetary policy committee in order to continue reducing interest rates when the existing members refused. This refusal to raise interest rates to control runaway inflation will continue to devalue the Lira driving it above $16. I do believe global inflation will start to be reigned in as COVID ends and central banks around the world begin liftoff from emergency low interest rates. However I think there is a chance this is actually detrimental to the Lira, as Turkey's refusal to follow suite will only devalue to Lira even more when compared to currencies where central banks are taking proper inflation control measures.

The lira is falling again. 
- I don’t think many of those Russian tourists are coming this spring. Or indeed many tourists at all. 
- Not sure who and when pays for the Bayraktars. 
- Trade going through the Black Sea may be restricted. 
- Other possible sources of hard currency?
Lira holding right around 14. Interesting given the strength in oil prices which they have to import.

The war in Ukraine will likely have an effect on the lira, but it mainly depends on whether the national (or rather presidents) monetary policy changes.  If they don’t touch base rates the exchange rate will worsen.
TRY has stabilised in a narrow band around13.5. Does not look like it is going anywhere.

A strong tourism season would support the lira. That would, of course, require no travel restrictions or major Covid scares, and by 26 May the tourism season will just be getting started (e.g., sea water temperatures still a bit low in much of Turkey; school calendars going until June in much of the world).  
“Can tourism ease the inflation pressure in Turkey?” https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-60262964

library(dplyr)
library(readr)
currency<-"TRY=X"
stDt <- as.Date(Sys.time())
endDt <- as.Date("2022-05-26")    
forecastBands <- c(-Inf,8,10,12,14,16,Inf)
remainingCloses<-sum(!weekdays(seq(stDt, endDt, "days")) %in% c("Saturday", "Sunday"))
#start date is 16/11/2021 start of recent volatility
histData<-read_csv(
  paste0(
    "https://query1.finance.yahoo.com/v7/finance/download/"
    , currency
    , "?period1=1610923429&period2="
    , floor(as.numeric(as.POSIXct(Sys.time())))
    , "&interval=1d&events=history&includeAdjustedClose=true"
  )
)
pricehistory<-as.numeric(histData$`Adj Close`)
pricehistory<-pricehistory[!is.na(pricehistory)]
spot<-pricehistory[length(pricehistory)]
sdMovementRatio <- sd(log(pricehistory[1:length(pricehistory)-1]/pricehistory[2:(length(pricehistory))]))
simulation<-spot*replicate(10000,
                           cumprod(exp(rnorm(
                             remainingCloses,mean = 0, sd = sdMovementRatio
                           )))[remainingCloses]) cutSimulation<-as_tibble(cut(simulation,forecastBands))
mutate(count(cutSimulation,value),n/sum(n))

We have some detail of what the Lira deposit top-up scheme looks like: https://ahvalnews.com/turkish-lira/turkish-capital-trickles-deposit-scheme-designed-bolster-lira and https://www.dailysabah.com/business/finance/ministry-reveals-details-of-turkeys-fx-protected-lira-scheme The key information as I understand it:
- People can put their savings in a special protected account, where it is guaranteed 14% interest (vs approx. 22.5% in a 'normal' Lira deposit account)
- Provides additional income linked to the lira’s value against the dollar should the lira lose more than that amount
- People are required to invest the money for a minimum of three months, and they lose all rights to profits should they withdraw capital early One immediate problem with these accounts is that they pay significantly lower interest rates, so it's in the interest of account holders for the Lira to slide in value, since that is the only way they can make a profit (inflation is at ~40%, so any current account is becoming significantly less valuable, but these ones even more so).  It seems like perhaps the treasury is using that interest rate gap to build it's own buffer (maybe by buying dollars with the difference), but it is quite a gamble given their downside possibilities. The reportedly low take-up might actually be what they wanted, since the announcement of the scheme seemed to trigger the rally. I'm still of the view that the Lira will devalue this year, but i'm not confident on the degree of devaluation or when. Once it slides a 'small' amount, e.g. to 14-14.5, then at that point the treasury will have to start making top up payments, and if they have to do that it could create a feedback mechanism. But with inflation rates so high and no sign of raising interest rates, it cannot keep up with the dollar, even if there is volatility there too. I've updated my forecast to make 16+ less likely for two reasons:
- I don't know how long the confidence will last
- I have spent a long time way above the crowd forecast on 16+, and haven't updated this forecast in a while so I need to compensate for that (if i'd updated more regularly, then my 16+ bucket would be higher)

"Nebati reiterated that the central bank and state-run banks did not intervene in the currency markets to help engineer last week’s rally. Official data appeared to show that the central bank spent billions of dollars to support the lira."
"... central bank’s benchmark rate of 14 percent." Given the refusal to increase interest rates (and, in fact, cuts), it's unlikely the trends inflation and currency devaluation will slow down or reverse. Despite whatever intervention/not-intervention occurred late December, the exchange rate has largely rebounded already. Rough napkin math-wise, a CPI of 21% versus a central bank rate of 14% means about a 6% devaluation annually, or 2.5% devaluation by the end of May. The lira currently sits at about 13.5, so that gives us 13.85. Volatility has been enormous recently though, making it hard to use point estimates, and future expectations matter more than current numbers. Also, CPI has been a on a steady tear, and 21% is conservative: https://tradingeconomics.com/turkey/inflation-cpi

Erdogan forced the central bank to cut interest rates, to 14%, in the belief that high interest rates fuel inflation. The immediate result was a jump in the exchange rate for the lira, at 18 to the dollar, and a flight to dollars and euros. He's also now planning to back the lira with the dollar, meaning Turkish taxpayers will be bailing out Turkish depositors, which will likely rile up the taxpayers, making for more political turmoil. He seems to be jumping headlong into disaster.

Wow, a real twist in this market occurred yesterday evening: https://www.reuters.com/markets/currencies/turkish-lira-charges-back-after-erdogans-anti-dollarization-plan-2021-12-21/ My reading of this is that the government has promised to make up the shortfall between bank deposits in Lira and the equivalent deposit in US Dollars, with the cost met by the Turkish Treasury. The effect of this announcement has allowed the Lira to stage a huge comeback and it is now trading at ~13 USD/TRY again. According to https://www.reuters.com/markets/currencies/turkish-lira-near-record-low-erdogan-defends-low-rates-2021-12-20/ - 
"The most important piece is that the government says that it will make up for losses in lira deposits if the lira declines exceed interest rates promised by banks. The government did not say how exactly they would execute this plan" A couple of key questions on the plan will be:
- Is there a limit to how much the treasury will top up deposits to make them equivalent
- How often/when will the deposit top-ups be made
- What will the baseline rate be? e.g. will deposits be guaranteed from the time of the announcement's price? 18TRY to USD? I think this announcement was made to improve confidence, but I don't see how it could work in practice. If the Lira slides and the treasury has to mint more Lira to cover the difference for people's deposits, then it will devalue the currency even more. It feels like an attempt to solve the Trilemma (https://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/trilemma.asp), e.g. trying to fix the exchange rate to the dollar using confidence. Maybe capital controls will be introduced quickly now that the exchange rate is more favourable?
Decisive move lower on Erdowan basically saying he will raise rates to make depositors whole.

https://www.reuters.com/markets/currencies/turkish-lira-near-record-low-erdogan-defends-low-rates-2021-12-20/ More reserves spent buoying the currency, but that can't go on forever. It also sounds like more interest rate cuts are on the way. Maybe a risk for this question is if the Turkish government introduces capital controls to stabilise the currency, but I'm not sure whether this would be done to restore value or preserve it.

Looking forward, we estimate it to trade at 12.82 in 12 months time.”
https://tradingeconomics.com/turkey/currency Turkish lira previously went through redenomination, with today’s lira (TRY), previously known as Yeni Türk Lirası, introduced into circulation in 2005. People in Turkey still sometimes use “millions” in everyday speech and in the bazaars, i.e., “five million” to mean 5 TRY.  From Wiki:
“The Guinness Book of Records ranked the Turkish lira as the world's least valuable currency in 1995 and 1996, and again from 1999 to 2004. The lira's value had fallen so far that one original gold lira coin could be sold for T₤154,400,000 before the 2005 revaluation. In December 2003, the Grand National Assembly of Turkey passed a law that allowed for redenomination by the removal of six zeros from the Turkish lira, and the creation of a new currency.”

Couple of points to consider:
- Lira has fallen 23% this month (November 2020), over 40% this year
- The lira fell 15% at one point on Tuesday [Nov 23] alone, ending the day with its largest daily drop since its tumultuous 2018 crisis, and analysts are worried the declines could rumble on.
- The crux is that the country's central bank is bowing to political pressure from President Erdogan to deliver interest rate cuts despite 20% inflation that could reach 30% or even 50%,  if the lira can't recover.
https://www.reuters.com/markets/europe/free-falling-lira-puts-turkey-balance-payments-danger-2021-11-24/  The logic of the government is, or rather seems to be, that with lower interest the Lira will weaken, therefore Turkish exports will increase in the coming months; also, lower interest rate would make credits cheaper and this will cause increase in domestic demand which leads to economic growth. 
HOWEVER, this rather simplistic view of the economic policy will worsen the already high inflation - what's the opposite of nosedive? 
When the inflation gets out of hand, people will short Lira - i.e., converting their savings and investment into major currencies such as USD. Hence, more weakening of Lira. Also, there is a possibility that foreign investments will get suspended; who wants to hold an asset in an unpredictable currency? 
Turkey is a heavy importer on energy and agricultural sector => higher inflation (with Lira loosing its value) => more capital flight => output shrinks => increase in price (even higher inflation)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VWA4ZuBPX_o
[Turkish lira in freefall after Erdogan moves to expel ambassadors || Oct 25, 2021]
See the vicious cycle? 
As for the question, I don't think Erdogan will respond to the reality of the situation; I'm assuming he will double down, which worsens the situation.  At the moment, USD/Lira is 12.43
Considering that in the recent history, the Lira was in declining mode, and judging by Erdogan's personality - for example, trying to divert attention by expelling several ambassadors - I'm guessing the current situation is the best in the coming 12 months even.

Until March the Lira was below 8USD. Since then a belief held by President Ergogan that high interest rates cause high inflation has led to him dismissing central bank governors and effectively pushing down the interest rate. It's hard to get an outside view on this because the volatility of the currency has been increasing for ~10 years and the bottom bin covers pretty much everything that would be covered by a long term view. Though there are examples of currencies heading into hyperinflation, it's hard to find examples of currencies that looked like they might but didn't, so if anyone has such examples i'd be interested to know. I think the horizon on this question is too short for the currency to repair itself to below 8. Erdogan doesn't seem likely to change policy and there are no elections till 2023.  If there is a reversion to higher interest rates, then perhaps the Lira could recover to the 8-10 bucket/10-12 bucket. However the reason the currency has drifted recently is because monetary policy has loosened, and it seems that the person directing those changes fundamentally believes that loosening policy results in lower inflation. As long as this view is maintained but not justified the currency will continue to slide.
